issue.title: npm install not working with binaries
issue.body:
Hello, I have the problem that sometimes the dependencies are not installed with npm, sometimes the deployments work and sometimes they don't, I have tried with `npm ci` and `npm i`.

This is the actions [Test CI](https://github.com/nonodev96/nets4learning/actions/runs/6653306313/job/18079004478)

Steps to reproduce:
1. Commit with tag "v*" to start the runner

## Runner Version and Platform

* Ubuntu - latest 
* Node - 18

## What's not working?

```
sh: 1: craco: not found
Error: Process completed with exit code 127.
```

## File YAML

```yaml
name: 'Deploy'

on:
  push:
    tags:
      - 'v*'

jobs:
  deploy-stable:
    name: 'Deploy to netlify stable'
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: 'Create env file'
        run: |
          echo "${{ secrets.NETLIFY_ENV_FILE_STABLE }}" > .env.netlify
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
        with:
          submodules: recursive
      - name: Install Node.js, NPM and Yarn
        uses: actions/setup-node@v3
        with:
          node-version: 18
      - uses: jsmrcaga/action-netlify-deploy@v2.0.0
        with:
          NETLIFY_AUTH_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.NETLIFY_AUTH_TOKEN }}
          NETLIFY_SITE_ID: ${{ secrets.NETLIFY_SITE_ID_STABLE }}
          NETLIFY_DEPLOY_MESSAGE: "Deploy v${{ github.ref }}"
          NETLIFY_DEPLOY_TO_PROD: true
          INSTALL_COMMAND: npm ci
          BUILD_COMMAND: npm run build:netlify
          BUILD_DIRECTORY: 'build'
        env:
          NODE_OPTIONS: "--max_old_space_size=6144"
```

## Job Log Output

```log
Run jsmrcaga/action-netlify-deploy@v2.0.0
Run /home/runner/work/_actions/jsmrcaga/action-netlify-deploy/v2.0.0/entrypoint.sh

added 996 packages, and audited 997 packages in 1m

174 packages are looking for funding
  run `npm fund` for details

16 vulnerabilities (1 low, 15 high)

To address issues that do not require attention, run:
  npm audit fix

To address all issues (including breaking changes), run:
  npm audit fix --force

Run `npm audit` for details.

> nets4learning@1.9.6 build:netlify-snapshot
> craco build --mode netlify-snapshot

sh: 1: craco: not found
Error: Process completed with exit code 127.
```

issue.title: CRITICAL: Old runner pods get stucked in Terminating state once container in that pod still Running
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
CI is not working properly, some steps just exiting with code 1. 
CI runner controller always use maximum amount of runners. 
It should use only minimum number of runners always, except all min runners are overwhelmed and controller want to spin more runners

Old runner pods get stucked in Terminating state once container in that pod still Running
`kubectl delete pod` does not work at all, 
pod cannot be deleted, because container in that pod still running(not init container)

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Run some ci jobs, version of runner is latest - `v2.310.2`, in our case min 6 runners, max 12 runners
2. See that runners can get stuck in terminating state, also they have finalizers that not allowing pods gracefully terminated

To Reproduce from source code with test:
Create pod that have 2 init containers and one not init container that are `runner` container
Resources/mocks that need to reproduce bug:
- those 2 init containers should have `Completed` state 
- `runner` container should have `Running` state
- pod should have `Terminating` state
- pod should have finalizers

```
finalizers:
 - actions.summerwind.dev/runner-pod 
```


**Expected behavior**
Pods not getting stucked for 20 days or so.

Pods in terminating state that have finalizers and runned containers should be gracefully removed via runner controller in source code. We should not stop pods and remove finalizers manually.


## Runner Version and Platform
Orchestrator: Kubernetes 1.28
Container Management: Docker 
Version of your runner? v2.310.2
Debian, Ubuntu 20/22, Amazon Linux2
 
## What's not working?
CI is not working properly, some steps just exiting with code 1. 


## Temporary solution
I removed those pods via cleaning finalizers 

```
$ kubectl get pods --all-namespaces | grep Terminating | awk '{print $2 " --namespace=" $1}' | xargs kubectl patch pod -p '{"metadata":{"finalizers":null}}'

$ kubectl get pods --all-namespaces | grep Terminating | awk '{print $2 " --namespace=" $1}' | xargs kubectl delete pod

```

issue.title: Support "multi-choice" input type for manual workflows
issue.body:
**Describe the enhancement**
Current set of input types doesn't cover some use-cases for manual workflows

We use a single gh-action as an entrypoint of deploying packages from our monorepo, and sometimes we need to manually deploy several packages simultaneously. Up until now we  just went with a set of Booleans, so we could tick all the packages we needed to run our CI/CD against via UI. However, we speedily reached a [limit of 10 input values](https://github.com/actions/runner/issues/1928)

Introducing an input type that would store a, say,  json array could help:
```yaml
on:
  workflow_dispatch:
    inputs:
      name:
        type: multi-choice
        description: select packages
        options: 
        - go-service1
        - go-service2
        - py-service1
```

...and in fact would be more logical with less copy-paste overhead for our use-case

issue.title: Configuration tries to use the registration endpoint even when passed `--token <token>`
issue.body:
<!--
👋 You're opening a bug report against the GitHub Actions **runner application**.

🛑 Please stop if you're not certain that the bug you're seeing is in the runner application - if you have general problems with actions, workflows, or runners, please see the [GitHub Community Support Forum](https://github.community/c/code-to-cloud/52) which is actively monitored.  Using the forum ensures that we route your problem to the correct team.  😃
-->

**Describe the bug**
When running the configuration of the runner unattended, some means of authenticating is required. The documentation at https://docs.github.com/en/rest/actions/self-hosted-runners#create-a-registration-token-for-an-organization claims that a token from that endpoint can be used with the `--token <token>` option. Instead, the runner attempts to obtain a new one with a PAT that may or may not be passed to it (See [ConfigurationManager.cs#L111](https://github.com/actions/runner/blob/main/src/Runner.Listener/Configuration/ConfigurationManager.cs#L111)) In the case that it isn't, the configuration fails with a 404. 

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Obtain a registration token from `https://api.github.com/orgs/ORG/actions/runners/registration-token`, where `ORG` is a valid organization. Call this registration token `TOKEN`.
2. Run `./config --unattended --url https://github.com/ORG --token TOKEN`
3. An error is printed out and the runner exits 

**Expected behavior**
What is described to be possible in https://docs.github.com/en/rest/actions/self-hosted-runners#create-a-registration-token-for-an-organization

## Runner Version and Platform
Version 2.291.1, Commit 496ec0df97891bd8e50f4431d01874ac3ab75a93

OS of the machine running the runner? OSX/Windows/Linux/...
Linux, Ubuntu 20.04.4 LTS

## What's not working?
```
Http response code: NotFound from 'POST https://api.github.com/actions/runner-registration'
{"message":"Not Found","documentation_url":"https://docs.github.com/rest"}
Response status code does not indicate success: 404 (Not Found).
``` 

## Job Log Output
N/A

## Runner and Worker's Diagnostic Logs
N/A

comment.body:
~~For anyone running into this issue when trying to adapt a script they've found on the internet to run GA Runners in e.g. docker, make sure the `curl` call to the `actions/runners/registrationtoken` endpoint is actually `api.github.com/repos/${ORG}/${REPO}/...`, **not** `api.github.com/orgs/${ORG}/...`. The latter is for registering runners at the org level, the former is for the repository level.~~

Actually, you immediately get back `Resource not accessible by personal access token`. This is because, per the docs, you must give it **repository admin** privileges, which means you're opening up that repository to a security risk just to have this functionality, which sucks, because the alternative is opening up potentially sensitive runners to the organization because 1) they're the only runners creatable by PAT tokens in a quasi-secure way, and 2) you must have Github Enterprise to use runner groups, which are a security feature.

GG, Github. Actively working against OSSers trying to get stuff done securely.

issue.title: Fix `buildx` installation
issue.body:
This PR is a continuation of #2901.

I hadn't tested that change locally and didn't realize the Dockerfile did a multi-stage build.

This PR fixes the `buildx` installation to ensure that the binary is copied to the final stage.

I tested these changes locally to confirm that it works as expected.

issue.title: Using Environments without creating deployment automatically
issue.body:
**Current Situation:**
Every pipeline step that uses environments automatically creates a new deployment. [This seems to be wanted behavior](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/deployment/targeting-different-environments/using-environments-for-deployment#how-environments-relate-to-deployments).

**Problem**
Access to an ``environment`` might be also needed for other reasons than deployments. Like running integration tests (deployment already done; we want to assure correct behavior of latest deployment)

**Possible Solution**
Can we add an option to avoid an automatic deployment always when using ``environment``?
An idea might be to set an environment variable like `AUTO_DEPLOYMENT=false`.

**Additional information**
- [GitLab has option to specify what kind of action is done within environment](https://docs.gitlab.com/ee/ci/environments/#access-an-environment-for-preparation-or-verification-purposes)

comment.body: We used the script suggested here (using the GH API) to manually delete the environments periodically. It's really bad this isn't available as an option built into the GH repo...

issue.title: Config.sh getting stuck at the last steps
issue.body:
<!--

🛑 Please stop if you're not certain that the bug you're seeing is in the runner application - if you have general problems with actions, workflows, or runners, please see the [GitHub Community Support Forum](https://github.community/c/code-to-cloud/52) which is actively monitored.  Using the forum ensures that we route your problem to the correct team.  😃
-->

**Describe the bug**
Whenever i'm trying to setup a self-hosted runner on my own machine, it goes through every step but after it says "√ Runner successfully added" it gets stucked and i get the following message after a minute: "The HTTP request timed out after 00:01:40.".
When looking through the log file, i have the following message:
```
[2023-09-08 21:19:50Z WARN GitHubActionsService] GET request to https://pipelinesghubeus9.actions.githubusercontent.com/62ScAd50ROPlszVlJRnqvsHeGMXN3XZfiyyHwyXvp2ULUR3GJf/_apis/distributedtask/pools?poolType=Automation timed out after 100 seconds.
```
Weird thing is that i can access this link properly, doesn't looks like a firewall/internet problem.
When i access the link directly i get the following JSON:
```
{"$id":"1","innerException":null,"message":"The user 'System:PublicAccess;aaaaaaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaaaaaaaaaa' is not authorized to access this resource.","typeName":"Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Framework.Server.UnauthorizedRequestException, Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Framework.Server","typeKey":"UnauthorizedRequestException","errorCode":0,"eventId":3000}

I expect the config.sh file to run and setup my self-hosted runner properly.

comment.body:
Hello,

As concerning a work-around for the error : System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCanceledException, one possibility would be to use an older release of the actions-runner-linux64. Unfortunately, the oldest version I have access is actions-runner-linux-x64-2.310.0.tar.gz, which seems to me has the same problem. The question I have is whether there would be a way to access older versions? If yes who  I should contact to get access to prio releases?

issue.title: Config.sh getting stuck at the last steps
issue.body:
<!--
👋 You're opening a bug report against the GitHub Actions **runner application**.

🛑 Please stop if you're not certain that the bug you're seeing is in the runner application - if you have general problems with actions, workflows, or runners, please see the [GitHub Community Support Forum](https://github.community/c/code-to-cloud/52) which is actively monitored.  Using the forum ensures that we route your problem to the correct team.  😃
-->

**Describe the bug**
Whenever i'm trying to setup a self-hosted runner on my own machine, it goes through every step but after it says "√ Runner successfully added" it gets stucked and i get the following message after a minute: "The HTTP request timed out after 00:01:40.".
When looking through the log file, i have the following message:
```
[2023-09-08 21:19:50Z WARN GitHubActionsService] GET request to https://pipelinesghubeus9.actions.githubusercontent.com/62ScAd50ROPlszVlJRnqvsHeGMXN3XZfiyyHwyXvp2ULUR3GJf/_apis/distributedtask/pools?poolType=Automation timed out after 100 seconds.
```
Weird thing is that i can access this link properly, doesn't looks like a firewall/internet problem.
When i access the link directly i get the following JSON:
```
{"$id":"1","innerException":null,"message":"The user 'System:PublicAccess;aaaaaaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaa-aaaaaaaaaaaa' is not authorized to access this resource.","typeName":"Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Framework.Server.UnauthorizedRequestException, Microsoft.TeamFoundation.Framework.Server","typeKey":"UnauthorizedRequestException","errorCode":0,"eventId":3000}
```

**Expected behavior**
I expect the config.sh file to run and setup my self-hosted runner properly.

## Runner Version and Platform
Linux x64 2.308.0

Running on Ubuntu 22.04

## What's not working?
The config.sh file is freezing at the last step.

## Job Log Output
If applicable, include the relevant part of the job / step log output here.  All sensitive information should already be masked out, but please double-check before pasting here.

As mentioned before the error is : System.Threading.Tasks.TaskCanceledException.  As work-around you did mention that the system administrator should deactivate IPv6 but since I have no superuser rights, the question  is whether there would be anything I could do besides de-activating IPv6 to make it work?

issue.title: Support "multi-choice" input type for manual workflows
issue.body:
**Describe the enhancement**
Current set of input types doesn't cover some use-cases for manual workflows

We use a single gh-action as an entrypoint of deploying packages from our monorepo, and sometimes we need to manually deploy several packages simultaneously. Up until now we  just went with a set of Booleans, so we could tick all the packages we needed to run our CI/CD against via UI. However, we speedily reached a [limit of 10 input values](https://github.com/actions/runner/issues/1928)

Introducing an input type that would store a, say,  json array could help:
```yaml
on:
  workflow_dispatch:
    inputs:
      name:
        type: multi-choice
        description: select packages
        options: 
        - go-service1
        - go-service2
        - py-service1
```

...and in fact would be more logical with less copy-paste overhead for our use-case

issue.title: Error parsing `fromJson` from a reusable "matrixed" workflow
issue.body:
# Describe the bug
It seems there is an error when using parsing JSON with `fromJSON` when already inside a "matrixed" nested workflow.

## what works, but doesn't fit my needs
- a job `pre_test` defines a JSON structure
- then ext job, `test`, uses the structure to populate a matrix
- the `test` job then proceeds to call a reusable workflow with a two-dimensional matrix. One dimension is the runner's architecture (arm64, amd64) and the other is the JSON structure.
- the problem here is that I'd like to have a specific JSON structure for each runner. To achieve that, the workflow needs to be changed a bit, to something that sadly, and inexplicably, fails.

## what would fit my needs, but doesn't work
- a job defines a one-dimensional matrix, for the runner's architecture
- it then proceeds to call a reusable workflow
- the called workflow starts with a first job `pre_test` that defines a JSON structure
- it then proceeds to a second job `test` that parses the JSON structure to create a matrix <-- error here
- the matrix is then iterated with another call to another workflow

The error (see https://github.com/ShutdownRepo/github-actions-nested-workflows/actions/runs/4118994038):
```
Error when evaluating 'strategy' for job 'test'. [...]/.github/workflows/test.yml@[...] (Line: 41, Col: 16): 
   Error parsing fromJson,[...]/github-actions-nested-workflows/.github/workflows/test.yml@[...] (Line: 41, Col: 16): 
      Error reading JToken from JsonReader. Path '', line 0, position 0.,[...]/github-actions-nested-workflows/.github/workflows/test.yml@[...] (Line: 41, Col: 16): 
         Unexpected type of value '', expected type: Sequence.
```

The way the JSON structure is passed to the matrix is exactly the same in both methods, but the runner fails at parsing when doing so from a "matrixed" reusable workflow.

# Reproduce

**entrypoint.yml**
```yaml
name: Main

on:
  push:
    branches:
      - '**'


jobs:
  belt_conveyor:
    name: Belt
    uses: ./.github/workflows/belt.yml
    with:
      SUPPORTED_ARCH: '["amd64","arm64"]'
```

**belt.yml**
```yaml
name: Belt

on:
  workflow_call:
    inputs:
      SUPPORTED_ARCH:
        required: true
        type: string

jobs:
  pre_test:
    name: L1 prepping matrix
    strategy:
      matrix:
        arch: ${{ fromJson(inputs.SUPPORTED_ARCH) }}
    runs-on:
      - self-hosted
      - ${{ matrix.arch }}
    steps:
      - name: Create matrix
        id: prepare
        run: |
          echo "matrix_tests=[\"['aaa', 'bbb', 'ccc']\",\"['ddd', 'eee', 'fff']\"]" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
    outputs:
      matrix_tests: ${{ steps.prepare.outputs.matrix_tests }}
  test:
    name: L1 handling matrix
    needs:
      - pre_test
    if: ${{ always() && needs.pre_test.result == 'success' }}
    strategy:
      fail-fast: false
      matrix:
        arch: ${{ fromJson(inputs.SUPPORTED_ARCH) }}
        batch: ${{ fromJson(needs.pre_test.outputs.matrix_tests) }}
    uses: ./.github/workflows/batch.yml
    with:
      ARCH: ${{ matrix.arch }}
      TESTS: ${{ matrix.batch }}
  nested:
    name: Calling L2 workflow
    strategy:
      fail-fast: false
      matrix:
        arch: ${{ fromJson(inputs.SUPPORTED_ARCH) }}
    uses: ./.github/workflows/test.yml
    with:
      ARCH: ${{ matrix.arch }}
```

**test.yml**
```yaml
on:
  workflow_call:
    inputs:
      ARCH:
        required: true
        type: string


jobs:
  pre_test:
    name: L2 prepping matrix
    runs-on:
      - self-hosted
      - ${{ inputs.ARCH }}
    steps:
      - name: Create matrix
        id: prepare
        run: |
          echo "matrix_tests=[\"['aaa', 'bbb', 'ccc']\",\"['ddd', 'eee', 'fff']\"]" >> $GITHUB_OUTPUT
    outputs:
      matrix_tests: ${{ steps.prepare.outputs.matrix_tests }}
  debug:
    name: L2 debug
    runs-on:
      - self-hosted
      - ${{ inputs.ARCH }}
    needs: pre_test
    if: ${{ always() && needs.pre_test.result == 'success' }}
    steps:
      - name: Read tests
        run: |
          echo "${{ needs.pre_test.outputs.matrix_tests }}"
          echo "${{ fromJson(needs.pre_test.outputs.matrix_tests) }}"
  test:
    name: L2 handling matrix
    needs: pre_test
    if: ${{ always() && needs.pre_test.result == 'success' }}
    strategy:
      fail-fast: false
      matrix:
        batch: ${{ fromJson(needs.pre_test.outputs.matrix_tests) }}
    uses: ./.github/workflows/batch.yml
    with:
      ARCH: ${{ inputs.ARCH }}
      TESTS: ${{ matrix.batch }}
```

**batch.yml**
```yaml
on:
  workflow_call:
    inputs:
      ARCH:
        required: true
        type: string
      TESTS:
        required: true
        type: string

jobs:
  test:
    runs-on:
      - self-hosted
      - ${{ inputs.ARCH }}
    strategy:
      fail-fast: false
      matrix:
        value: ${{ fromJson(inputs.TESTS) }}
    steps:
      - name: Print values
        run: |
          echo ${{ matrix.value }}
```

## Runner Version and Platform

Tested with runner version: `2.301.1`, on Linux (amd64) and macOS (arm64).

issue.title: GitHub Actions `hashFiles` empty output using `?`

labels.name: keep
labels.description: Label can be added as soon as we are sure the work on the issue is necessary

issue.body:
_(Migrated from https://support.github.com/ticket/personal/0/2315150 as suggested by GitHub Support)_

As per the [GitHub Actions expression `hashFiles` documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/learn-github-actions/expressions#hashfiles),

> _You can use pattern matching characters to match file names. For more information about supported pattern matching characters, see https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#filter-pattern-cheat-sheet_

That cheat sheet states that `?` can be used to match zero or one of the preceding character, but it doesn't work with hashFiles and produces an empty output instead. Is this the expected behavior?

### Minimal example
My expectation is that the two examples below should be equivalent.

```yaml
on: push
jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - run: touch file.ts file.tsx
      - run: echo ${{ hashFiles('*.tsx?') }} # empty output
      - run: echo ${{ hashFiles('*.ts', '*.tsx') }} # correct hash
```

issue.title: GitHub Actions `hashFiles` empty output using `?`

labels.name: keep
labels.description: Label can be added as soon as we are sure the work on the issue is necessary

issue.body:
_(Migrated from https://support.github.com/ticket/personal/0/2315150 as suggested by GitHub Support)_

As per the [GitHub Actions expression `hashFiles` documentation](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/learn-github-actions/expressions#hashfiles),

> _You can use pattern matching characters to match file names. For more information about supported pattern matching characters, see https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#filter-pattern-cheat-sheet_

That cheat sheet states that `?` can be used to match zero or one of the preceding character, but it doesn't work with hashFiles and produces an empty output instead. Is this the expected behavior?

### Minimal example
My expectation is that the two examples below should be equivalent.

```yaml
on: push
jobs:
  test:
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - run: touch file.ts file.tsx
      - run: echo ${{ hashFiles('*.tsx?') }} # empty output
      - run: echo ${{ hashFiles('*.ts', '*.tsx') }} # correct hash
```

pull_request.title: Fix `buildx` installation
pull_request.body:
This PR is a continuation of #2901.

I hadn't tested that change locally and didn't realize the Dockerfile did a multi-stage build.

This PR fixes the `buildx` installation to ensure that the binary is copied to the final stage.

I tested these changes locally to confirm that it works as expected.

comment.body:
Hi, I have the same problem, sometimes the deployments work for me and other times they don't, I have tried `npm ci` and `npm i` and it is the same.


```yaml
name: 'Deploy'

on:
  push:
    tags:
      - 'v*'

jobs:
  deploy-stable:
    name: 'Deploy to netlify stable'
    runs-on: ubuntu-latest
    steps:
      - name: 'Create env file'
        run: |
          echo "${{ secrets.NETLIFY_ENV_FILE_STABLE }}" > .env.netlify
      - uses: actions/checkout@v3
        with:
          submodules: recursive
      - name: Install Node.js, NPM and Yarn
        uses: actions/setup-node@v3
        with:
          node-version: 18
      - uses: jsmrcaga/action-netlify-deploy@v2.0.0
        with:
          NETLIFY_AUTH_TOKEN: ${{ secrets.NETLIFY_AUTH_TOKEN }}
          NETLIFY_SITE_ID: ${{ secrets.NETLIFY_SITE_ID_STABLE }}
          NETLIFY_DEPLOY_MESSAGE: "Deploy v${{ github.ref }}"
          NETLIFY_DEPLOY_TO_PROD: true
          INSTALL_COMMAND: npm ci
          BUILD_COMMAND: npm run build:netlify
          BUILD_DIRECTORY: 'build'
        env:
          NODE_OPTIONS: "--max_old_space_size=6144"
```
